mainClaim: Independent contractor status in gig work denies workers essential protections while giving companies control without responsibilities
evidence: UC Berkeley study of 120,000 gig workers found 73% earn below minimum wage after expenses, with zero paid sick leave, healthcare, or retirement benefits. Uber's own data leaked in 2024 showed median driver works 52 hours weekly for $9.73/hour after costs. Algorithmic management exercises employer-level control - dispatching, pricing, discipline - without corresponding duties. California's AB5 implementation increased Lyft driver compensation 30% while maintaining flexibility.
supportingPoints: Workers bear all risk: vehicle costs, insurance, maintenance, no unemployment protection
No discrimination protections - apps can deactivate workers without recourse
Asymmetric information - platforms control all data about earnings and opportunities
Creates two-tier labor system with second-class workers
limitations: Some workers genuinely prefer flexibility and multiple platforms. Optimal classification may be neither pure employee nor contractor. Need portable benefits solutions. Implementation challenges in California show regulatory complexity.
